awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Light Driven Evaporation System for Desalination
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project will deploy a nanotechnology-based device to deliver fresh water, employing renewable energy and directed toward applications in sectors such as individual use, small-scale household, municipality, or industrial use.  The initial application will be developed for small municipalities and individuals in high-mineral-content aquifer-supplied regions, with subsequent translation to include brine management for desalination plants and fresh water recovery for saltwater disposal companies.  Our community will include teachers from the highly diverse and majority disadvantaged Houston Independent School District (86% minority enrollment) in a Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program and an undergraduate student from Houston Community College, a school with a majority Hispanic and African-American student body.  

The proposed project addresses the critical need for compact, innovative technologies that create safe drinking water from water over a range of salinities, which do not require large-scale infrastructure, but can be deployed even in remote, needy areas.  Our objective is to design and build a compact prototype system to achieve the benchmark goal of 1 gal/min clean water production.  The core technology combines small-scale optical elements, an optimized thermal oscillator-driven energy recovery, and the use of efficient light-absorbing nanoparticles that generate heat and locally vaporize water.  This project will combine advanced theoretical models and numerical multiphysics techniques, already tested quantitatively against experimental pilot studies, to guide the fabrication of optimized desalination units.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: This project aims at realizing a light-powered, pilot-scale thermal desalination system based on nanoscale localized heating. Access to safe drinking water is a fundamental need of every human being. Almost every country in the world, including the US, periodically faces water shortages, especially in regions lacking a water grid or having access to only non-potable underground brackish water. Relatively efficient desalination and filtration systems exist but require large scale infrastructure, fossil fuels for operation, and their local deployment is impractical, especially to remote, needy areas. This project will deliver a scalable multilayer water purification device capable of purifying water with a wide range of salinity, with a target capacity of 1 gal/min of produced fresh water. The core technology (funded under NSF Award EEC-1449500, ERC Nanotechnology Enabled Water Treatment) is based on the combination of small-scale optical elements, optimized energy recovery and the use of efficient light-absorbing nanoparticles which generate heat and locally vaporize water. These innovations revolutionize the conventional approach to thermal desalination, usually limited in size and constrained by input energy source. The initial target customer segment for the proposed system is represented by small municipalities and individuals in high-mineral-content aquifer-supplied regions. Potential follow-up markets include brine management for desalination plants and freshwater recovery for Saltwater Disposal Companies. The market segments result from an extensive valuable product opportunity search carried out during an I-Corps customer discovery process (NSF I-Corps Team award IIP - 1745213, Nanophotonics Enabled Solar Membrane Distillation).

 

Intellectual Merit: This project helps advance the knowledge of nanotechnology driven, macroscale systems. Extensive research of the last two decades on fundamental nanoscale mechanisms is now mature, with applications in multiphysics and multiscale devices. This project integrates nanoparticles in a microscale membrane to convert light energy into heat, to promote vapor diffusion within nanopores. The combination of optical elements and engineered energy recovery, scaled to large areas, helps deliver fresh water at varying capacities. This project combines advanced theoretical models and numerical techniques to properly guide the fabrication of optimized desalination units. The parallel experimental and theoretical activity represents a fundamental aspect of the technology development towards its commercialization.

 

Broader Impacts: This PFI-TT project has far-reaching societal impacts from multiple points of view. The project deploys a nanotechnology-based device to deliver fresh water, employing renewable solar energy and artificial lighting. It shows how fundamental research and environmental awareness can be combined to provide an essential element to life. The use of cost-effective materials and optimized manufacturing process can unlock the international widespread adoption of the system, especially in those regions where drinkable water represents a first concern for the population daily. Successful accomplishment of this project will be possible through the engagement, education, and collaboration of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who will merge different educational specialties and skill sets, from nanofabrication to numerical simulations. A continuous mentoring activity from PIs, senior researchers and business experts will create an ideal environment for students and junior researchers to succeed in both basic research and technology transfer.
